Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: or I guess that is what the `minutes -= 59;` is for in the interest function

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: but it still means you don't have to wait an hour to start accruing rewards like most normal users if you manually set nLocktime just under an hour in the past, right?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we had a compound interest attack that did that

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so there is a one hour setback

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: awww

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I was gonna try that

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: :trollface:

Content: nice locktime

Author: jorian#4555

Author: lukechilds#2707

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content:
Btw, I think there are some errors here:
https://komodoplatform.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/KPSD/pages/71729215/What+is+the+5+Komodo+Stake+Reward

```
The 5% reward starts accumulating after a few minutes if you hold over 10 KMD in your wallet.
```

It will more likely be around an hour not a few minutes if nLockTime is set slightly in the past.

```
It is very similar to POS 
```
And then in the next line:
```
KMD's POS is a hybrid zero footprint proof of stake
```

These two statements seem to contradict each other, saying it's **similar** to PoS and then saying it **is** PoS then saying it's **hybrid** PoS.

Also, it's completely unrelated to PoS, it's not a consensus mechanism. I think the comparison to PoS is confusing, PoS should either not be mentioned at all, or only be mentioned purely to explain that Komodo is not PoS and KMD rewards are nothing to do with stake rewards.

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I don't think I have the ability to edit this myself so CC @SHossain @PTYX

Author: lukechilds#2707
hyperDEX#6586
Content: @lukechilds Great Job!

Author: Alright#0419
Content: @lukechilds nlocktime is just a limit on the earliest time a transaction can be included in a block

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: @Alright I'm aware of that, but I mistakenly set it to 777, which as a unix timestamp evaluates to 01/01/1970 @ 12:12am. The network is supposed to reject transactions older than one hour. So I'm wondering how that transaction was accepted.

Author: Alright#0419
Content: pm'd you

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: anything less than 500 mil is treated as height and the interest calc will ignore it

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: Yeah, just figured that out in my testing, `nLockTime >= LOCKTIME_THRESHOLD` to the rescue

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: btw @jl777c what happens if the client interest calcs are slightly under the `komodod` calcs?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: say the client is under by 100 sats

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: does the miner calculate the interest and realise there are an extra unused 100 sats and credit it to himself in the block reward?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: or are those 100 sats just never minted?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: miner gets unclaimed interest

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: Thanks

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: oh and one more thing

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: If you set nLocktime more than an hour in the past the TX gets rejected

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: is that a normal BTC rule

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: or was that added to KMD due to the supply infaltion bug

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: BTC allows any time from the past

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it was added to prevent the backdating of utxo, also it achieves mempool expiration

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so after an hour if you tx isnt confirmed you dont have to worry about it confirming sometime in the next week

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: Can you expand on mempool expiration a little? I'm not quite sure I understand

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: oh you just mean if it doesn't get confirmed in an hour, it won't be floating around in the mempool for an unkonwn amount of time, it'll be removed from the mempool because it's now invalid? Is that correct?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: got it

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: just an idea

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: but what would happen if you submitted a transaction with an nLocktime of 59 mins in the past, the network accepts it because it's valid, but the next block takes 2 mins to mine, so your transaction is technically invalid at the time the block is mined

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: would the block be invalid?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: or would the network accept it?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: just trying to figure out how far back I can safely set nLocktime to maximise users rewards

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is a consensus rule

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: but obvs don't wanna cause failed transactions/blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I set it back 777 seconds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the extra satoshis compared to the frustration of a tx being invalidated

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: true, was also just kinda interested in that scenario as a thought experiment

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: so when you say it's a consensus rule, you mean that the nodes would validate all the TXs in the block, treat that TX as invalid and discard the entire block as invalid? Is that correct?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: any block with that tx mined in it will get rejected

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a sad miner will be

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: ok, wasn't sure if maybe the timestamp in the block header would be used to check the date instead of the time receiving the block. As you could then verify that the miner was following the rules

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i think it is using the block timestamp so it can know during block construction it is invalid

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in any case, nothing good comes from pushing too close to the edge

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we used to get 30 min+ between blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: now that doesnt seem to be the case anymore, but still always possible to get a long time between blocks

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: but a lot of good comes from finding exactly where the edge is so you can be sure you don't go past it ðŸ˜‰

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I only go 777 seconds back out of 3600

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: and teh reason for going back 777 instead of 0 is to account for node clock variation so out of (time) sync nodes don't discard yout TX, correct?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also the actual check is not current time but the median blocktime of the past 17 block window

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: or about 9 minutes in the past

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: oh interesting

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: so if you set nLocktime as -59 mins then you could end up trying to claim a reward before it existed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: little know quirk that makes some CLTV claims fail by not being in the past enough

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe there is an extra 8 minutes in there that you can squeeze out

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: also

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: one other idea

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I just like to have it so the tx confirms and a setback of 777 achieves this in virtually all cases

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: yep I understand

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: what is the time drift allowed between different miner clocks?

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: not sure what the correct terminology is

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 60 seconds forward

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 10 minutes behind (I think)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes a dominant miner can likely gain an extra 10 minutes of rewards

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: yep

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: but yeah, I guess that's not a huge issues

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: if it's only 1 min forward

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: much bigger issues at play if there is such a dominant miner than fractional gains from rewards

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: wait, where does the extra 10 mins come from?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: blocktimestamps are arbitrary

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: I was gonna say they get extra fees becuase their clock is 1 min ahead of the clients clock that calcualted their interest

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: and other miners will accept that due to the 1 min drift allowance

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but it is the best time reference the blockchain has

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: but how do you go from 1 min extra to 10 mins extra?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there needs to be more negative timestamps allowed than forward timestamps

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: to avoid timewarp attacks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so you can have a block a minute from the future or 10 minutes in the past

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: but the negative timestamps won't affect interest will they? because the interest calcs are done via a users clock, not the blockhcain timestamps

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: *the interest calcs signed in the TX

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: unless there is a timewarp attack going on, it wont affect things

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: even with a timewarp attack going on, by back dating it 777 seconds, i think most cases are fine

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: calculate based on local clock, consensus based on previous blocktime and nLockTime

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there really are a lot of different things going on and getting a stable working consensus wasnt easy

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: now that it works, I dont want to fix it

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: yeah, I will definitely use 777 in our app

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: just wanted to understand how it worked

Author: lukechilds#2707
Content: thanks for taking the time to explain
